channel.title: Randodudem - A Damn Good Time [Jazzy, Downtempo]
channel.description:
Attempted to create something more acoustic than electronic; down to the choice of drums, horns, bass, etc. Very experimental (within the Auxy community, at least) but I had a blast while making this. Let me know if it works!
**https://soundcloud.com/dnl_d/a-damn-good-time**
![a damn good time|500x500](upload://nzkjgXiopS447OPWeQ2zh99joN5.png)

item.title: Randodudem - A Damn Good Time [Jazzy, Downtempo]
item.dc:creator: ThoughtfulNoise
item.description:
Cool. Yeah, the Auxy sounds can be a little hit n miss.
The brass can be really effective and convincing, when used the way you have.
They work well for those rich, warm chords.

(Side-note: Fantastic chords, by the way. Rich and lush extensions.
It’s cool to hear Auxy being used for more rich, extended chord compositions. With certain sounds, it can be really effective and compelling.)

Cool to hear that you’re interested in developing it further.

In the meantime, I’d suggest perhaps trying out some other basses, maybe even avoid the acoustic/electric bass guitar sound pack. It’s a tricky one to emulate well, and I don’t think the pack is particularly successful at achieving a convincing sound.
As it’s such a core part of your track, the cheapness really cuts.

Maybe there’s more that can be done while still in Auxy. Maybe a layered option; a sub with texture to flesh out the low-end (currently missing in your bass) and a little grit, then maybe layering on the slightest top-end of an electric bass for character?

(You might still need to subtly automate the LPF and volume of the electric bass, just to give some variance. Part of the main problem/giveaway of the current bass choice is the lack of variance in the slap/twang, etc…)

For a track like yours, it pays to have a clear idea of what bass you’re aiming to emulate.
For instance, the one you’ve used is quite slappy, which might not be the right sound for your track.
Perhaps listen again to some Zero 7 and others from the Downtempo genre to hear what choices they’ve made on their basses.

Do you also use a desktop DAW?
There are some really good, affordable electric bass VSTs around, and loads of great free/trial synth basses available.

Sax is more challenging. The good VSTs are expensive, and even then you need to really know what you’re doing to get something really convincing out of them.

(I’ve also got some sax sections in recent pieces that I need to step up on too. Some uses work better than others, with some parts still sounding very midi-fied. So, I’m looking at the options.)

Read full topic

item.title: Randodudem - A Damn Good Time [Jazzy, Downtempo]
item.dc:creator: dnldrl
item.description:
Wow, coincidentally enough, Zero 7 was actually my main inspiration for this piece (particularly, “Your Place” from “The Garden”). So hearing that this gives off Zero 7 vibes makes me jump for joy!

Indeed, I do wish some of the instruments sounded less artificial. I fiddled around with the pitch automation for the sax solo just to make it sound more realistic. But commissioning live parts on Fiverr sounds like a great idea!

Thanks for the thorough feedback!

Read full topic
item.source: Randodudem - A Damn Good Time [Jazzy, Downtempo]

item.title: Randodudem - A Damn Good Time [Jazzy, Downtempo]
item.dc:creator: ThoughtfulNoise
item.description:
Aesthetically, getting strong Zero 7 vibes. Early 00’s, jazzy, chilled Downtempo.* (so, not particularly experimental, given that the Downtempo genre is a thing.)

Cool take. Particularly like the quick movement around chords around 3:04. Some really sophisticated chord choices.

I definitely feel this deserves to be taken further, and rebuilt using better quality sounds - or even commission some live parts on Fiverr, especially the bass. It’s a good piece somewhat undermined by the quality of the sounds and sheer midi-ness of some parts. (Not sure Auxy can get this piece where it wants to go. You could try micro-shifting the vintage keys in free-mode to humanise it, possibly starting with the double-time section. But, there are probably less RSS-inducing ways to do it if you bump the midi and reference stems over to a desktop DAW.)

A really good piece with a great vibe. Really good work!

.

  • Jeez, is it really almost 20 years since Zero 7’s ‘Simple Things’ album?
    Btw, if you haven’t checked out Zero 7, do. I think you’ll get a kick out of them, if this is where your musical ear is at.

Read full topic
